column4: I have a computer (A) without a monitor, and behind a NAT. Computer A cannot accept incoming connections, it can only "dial out". Computer A runs Ubuntu. Computer B runs XP. I want to run my GUI programs on Computer A. I have installed XMing on computer B. How do I connect from A to B, so that my desktop is displayed on B, but the programs are run on A? Remember that A cannot accept incoming connections.
cannot accept incoming connections of any type?
no type at all. not even ping
you could have computer A initiate a VPN connection to computer B -- they you would be able to connect to Computer A through the VPN
I was thinking more along the lines of reverse XDMCP..
if you have access to the console, just type DISPLAY=computerb:0.0; xterm;
hmmm. that is not the correct behaviour
try some other X client, e.g. xeyes xclock
I put echo $DISPLAY into a new bash script then ran the script, and it came out blank
and yet, when I type echo $DISPLAY outside the script, it works
I assume this means that the DISPLAY variable is not going down into the script
and so is not going down into xterm either
I'm going to grep my hd for any DISPLAY= now
